item.title: Burn Hollywood Burn
item.dc:creator: Nathan Marsak
item.description:

Pajamarino, that time-honored tradition of frat boys garbing themselves in…pajamas!  And thereafter lighting everything they can get their hands on on fire.  And there’s something in there about football, and probably a booze-fueled orgy of rape and vandalism, but definitely… Continue reading Burn Hollywood Burn

The post Burn Hollywood Burn appeared first on 1947 Project.
item.content:encoded:
October 14, 1927
Glendale

Pajamarino!  Everybody loves pajamarino!  Everybody, except, perhaps, Mr. Charles Chaplin.

Pajamarino, that time-honored tradition of frat boys garbing themselves in…pajamas!  And thereafter lighting everything they can get their hands on on fire.  And there’s something in there about football, and probably a booze-fueled orgy of rape and vandalism, but definitely football.

Which is all fine and good, yet again, Mr. Chaplin would disagree, in that he showed up for work this morning ready to get to work on his new picture The Circus.  But two crucial props were missing…the circus wagons.  He and his crew of fifty were held up—at Chaplin’s expense—as deputy sheriffs set about searching for the missing things.  

They were located, finally, down on Moore Field at UCLA, apparently absconded with by the aforementioned Greeks of Occidental, who’d thrown them into the giant tower of chopped-up orphanages and dug-up caskets and whatnot ready for that night’s postgame bonfire.  

So Chaplin’s people pulled the wagons off and back to Glendale, the rest of the kindling was sent that night aflame to hell, the pajama-clad ran amok, and all was right with the world.

We’ve come for your circus wagons. 

 

The post Burn Hollywood Burn appeared first on 1947 Project.

item.content:encoded:
March 6, 2007
San Francisco (VIA Associated Press)

The Irish of San Francisco are furious over a play at the Davis Theater called Ã¢â‚¬Å“The Belle of Avenue A,Ã¢â‚¬Â which features a character named Mrs. McCluskey who drinks a glass of beer in the first act.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Three times, about 40 people charged the stage and the actors and actresses feared they were about to be attacked,Ã¢â‚¬Â The Times says.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indignant because the womanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s part in the first act called for the drinking of a glass of beer, two score men, members of the Irish societies of this city, charged the stage and for half an hour refused to allow the play to go on.Ã¢â‚¬Â

The riot was reported to the police and the protesters were eventually thrown out of the theater.
